result.heading: SHO-NUFF BY ANY MEANS NECESSARY WGA

dialogue.raw_text: by Spike Lee Second Draft March 1, 1988; Brooklyn, N.Y. Forty Acres and a Mule Filmworks, Inc. YA-DIG SHO-NUFF BY ANY MEANS NECESSARY WGA #45816 "The greatest miracle Christianity has achieved in America is that the black man in white Christian hands has not grown violent.  It is a miracle that 22 million black people have not risen up against their oppressors--in which they would have been justified by all moral criteria, and even by the democratic tradition!  It is a miracle that a nation of black people has so fervently continued to believe in a turn-the-other-cheek and heaven-for-you-after-you-die philosophy!  It is a miracle that the American Black people have remained a peaceful people, while catching all the centuries of hell that they have caught, here in white man's heaven!  The miracle is that the white man's puppet Negro 'leaders,' his preachers and the educated Negroes laden with degrees, and others who have been allowed to wax fat off their black poor brothers, have been able to hold the black masses quiet until now."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : INT: WE LOVE RADIO STATION STOREFRONT--DAY EXTREME CLOSE UP WE SEE only big white teeth and very Negroidal (big) lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waaaake up! Wake up!  Wake up!  Wake up! Up ya wake!  Up ya wake!  Up ya wake! CAMERA MOVES BACK SLOWLY TO REVEAL MISTER SENOR LOVE DADDY, a DJ, a radio personality, behind a microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Mister Senor Love Daddy. Your voice of choice.  The world's only twelve-hour strongman, here on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: radio, 108 FM.  The last on your dial, but the first in ya hearts, and that's the truth, Ruth! The CAMERA, which is STILL PULLING BACK, shows that Mister Senor Love Daddy is actually sitting in a storefront window. The control booth looks directly out onto the street.  This is WE LOVE RADIO, a modest station with a loyal following, right in the heart of the neighborhood.  The OPENING SHOT will be a TRICK SHOT--the CAMERA PULLING BACK through the storefront window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here I am.  Am I here?  Y'know it. It ya know.  This is Mister Senor Love Daddy, doing the nasty to ya ears, ya ears to the nasty.  I'se play only da platters dat matter, da matters dat platter and that's the truth, Ruth. He hits the cart machine and we hear a station jingle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doing da ying and yang da flip and flop da hippy and hoppy (he yodels) Yo da lay he hoo.  I have today's forecast. (he screams)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! He laughs like a madman. INT: DA MAYOR'S BEDROOM--DAY An old, grizzled man stirs in the bed, his sheets are soaked with sweat.  He flings them off his wet body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, it's hot. INT: JADE'S APARTMENT--DAY CAMERA MOVES IN ON a young man sitting at the edge of a sofa bed. CLOSE UP--HIS SMALL HANDS WE SEE him counting his money.  This isn't any ordinary counting of money, he's straightening out all the corners of the bills, arranging them so the bills--actually the "dead presidents"--are facing the same way.  This is MOOKIE.  Once he's finished with that task, counting his money, he sneaks into his sister's bedroom. INT: JADE'S BEDROOM--DAY CLOSE UP--JADE JADE, Mookie's sister, is fast asleep.  Mookie's fingers ENTER THE FRAME and start to play with her lips.  Jade pushes his hands away.  Mookie waits several beats and he continues.  Jade wakes up--mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you have enough sense not to bother people when they're sleeping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up?  Saturday is the lone day I get to sleep late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's gonna be hot today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good!  Leave me alone when I'm sleeping.  I'm gonna get a lock on my door, to keep ya ass outta here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't ya love ya brother Mookie anymore?  I loves ya, Jade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do me a favor.  Go to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later.  Gotta get paid. He plants a big fat juicy on his sister's forehead. EXT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY A 1975 El Dorado pulls up in front of the neighborhood pizzeria--Sal's Famous Pizzeria. From out of the car comes the owner, SAL, a slightly overweight man in his early fifties, and his two sons, PINO, 22, and VITO, 20.  It's time for them to go to work at Sal's Famous Pizzeria in the heart of Black Brooklyn.  Sal's sits on the corner of The Block.  The Block being where this film on the hottest day of the summer takes place. Pino kicks a beer can in his path into the gutter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pino, get a broom and sweep out front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vito, get a broom and sweep out front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, Pop.  That's just what I was talkin' about.  Every single time you tell Pino to do something, he gives it to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's nuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The both of youse, shaddup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Pino.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get the broom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't getting shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!  Watch it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't want to come to work anyway.  I hate this freakin' place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you do better?  C'mere. Pino is now silent.  Sal walks over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you do better? (he pops Pino upside the head) I didn't think so.  This is a respectable business.  Nuthin' wrong with it.  Get dat broom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Vito.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop asked you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna kill somebody today. EXT: MOOKIE'S BROWNSTONE--DAY Mookie comes down his stoop and walks to work. EXT: STREET--DAY The Block is beginning to come to life.  Those unlucky souls who have to work this Saturday drag themselves to it, and the kids are out on the street to play in the hot sun all day long. EXT: MOTHER SISTER'S STOOP--DAY Mookie stops to say hello to MOTHER SISTER.  She leans out her window on the parlor floor.  In the summertime, the only time when she's not perched in her window is when she's asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Mookie, don't work too hard today.  The man said it's gonna be
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the devil.  I don't want ya falling out from the heat.  You hear me, son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear ya, Mother Sister.  I hear you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  I'll be watching ya, son. Mother Sister always watches. INT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY Mookie enters the pizzeria and Pino is on him before the door closes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mookie, late again.  How many times I gotta tell you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Sal.  Hello, Vito.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How ya doin', Mookie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whaddup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just coolin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're still late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pino, relax, will ya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, take the broom.  The front needs sweeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute.  Wait a minute.  I just got here.  You sweep.  I betcha Sal asked you first anyhow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shaddup, Vito.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck dat shit.  I deliver pizzas. That's what I get paid for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get paid to do what we say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What we say.  I didn't hear Sal say nuthin'. Pino looks at his father.  He wants to be backed up on this; all he gets is an amused look, and a smirk from Vito.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's working for who? There's a knock on the door and Da Mayor enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on in, Mayor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, gentlemens.  It's gonna be a scorcher today, that's for sure.  Need any work done around here? Sal looks at Pino, who reluctantly gives Da Mayor the broom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will be the cleanest sidewalk in Brooklyn.  Clean as the Board of Health. Da Mayor almost runs out of the pizzeria in his hurry; soon as he finishes he'll be able to get a bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop, I don't believe this shit.  We runnin' welfare or somethin'? Every day you give dat bum--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Da Mayor ain't no bum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give dat bum a dollar for sweeping our sidewalk.  What do we pay Mookie for?  He don't even work.  I work harder than him and I'm your own son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who don't work?  Let's see you carry six large pies up six flights of stairs.  No elevator either and shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both of youse--shaddup.  This is a place of business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell 'em, Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me and you are gonna have a talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sez who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sez me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!  What did I say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who doesn't work?  Don't start no shit, won't be no shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mookie, no cursing in the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to your son. EXT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY Da Mayor sweeps the sidewalk, happy as can be.  As soon as he finishes he can get that money and get that bottle. EXT: STOOP--DAY A group of youths sit on a stoop, waiting for someone.  They are CEE, PUNCHY, and the lone female, ELLA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's keeping him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You call him, then. Ella stands up and yells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yo, Ahmad!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I coulda done dat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yo, Ahmad! She looks up into his window, then sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Punchy, if ya want to do some more screaming, be my guest.  I'm too through. The door swings open at the top of the stoop and AHMAD appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's yelling my name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Punchy told me to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't listen to him, it will get ya in trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heard that, Punchy. Ahmad sits down with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ella, you have a brain, use it. In the BG, we hear the dum-dum-dum of a giant box.  The sound gets louder as the box gets closer.  The youths look down the block and see a tall young man coming towards them. He has a very distinct walk, it's more like a bop.  This is RADIO RAHEEM.  The size of his box is tremendous and one has to think, how does he carry something that big around with him?  It must weigh a ton, and it seems like the sidewalk shakes as the rap music blares out.  The song we hear is the only one Radio Raheem plays. MEDIUM SHOT--RADIO RAHEEM Radio Raheem stops in front of the group, looks at them, and turns down the volume.  It's quiet again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace, y'all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace, Radio Raheem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You the man, Radio Raheem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a big way. Radio Raheem nods and turns up the volume.  Way up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My people.  My people. EXT: WE LOVE STOREFRONT--DAY Radio Raheem waves to Mister Senor Love Daddy as he walks by. INT: WE LOVE CONTROL BOOTH--DAY Mister Senor Love Daddy gives Radio Raheem a clenched-fist salute. EXT: FRUIT-N-VEG DELIGHT--DAY Da Mayor walks into a newly opened fruit and vegetable deli stand that is owned by Koreans. INT: FRUIT-N-VEG DELIGHT--DAY Da Mayor is looking for his beer in the refrigerated cases, his ice-cold beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's the Bud?  Where's the Bud?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No mo' Bud.  You look what we have and buy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more Bud.  What kind of joint is this?  How come no mo' Bud?  Doctor, this ain't Korea, China, or wherever you come from.  Get some Budweiser in this motherfucker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You buy 'nother beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright.  Alright.  Y'know you're asking a lot to make a man change his beer, that's asking a lot, Doctor. EXT: MOTHER SISTER'S STOOP--DAY Da Mayor has his can of beer (not Budweiser) and the brown paper bag is twisted into a knot at the bottom.  He stops and takes a long swig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ole drunk.  What did I tell ya about drinking in front of my stoop? Move on, you're blocking my view. Da Mayor lowers the can from his mouth and looks up at his heckler.  It's obvious from the look on his face he's heard this before.  Da Mayor contorts his face and stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ugly enough.  Don't stare at me. Da Mayor changes his face into a more grotesque look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The evil eye doesn't work on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother Sister, you've been talkin' 'bout me the last eighteen years. What have I ever done to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a drunk fool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Besides that.  Da Mayor don't bother nobody.  Nobody don't bother Da Mayor but you.  Da Mayor just mind his business.  I love everybody. I even love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold your tongue.  You don't have that much love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One day you'll be nice to me.  We might both be dead and buried, but you'll be nice.  At least civil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Da Mayor tips his beat-up hat to Mother Sister and takes a final swig of beer just for her. INT: TINA'S APARTMENT--DAY An elderly Puerto Rican woman, CARMEN, is telling off her daughter TINA in Spanish.  Tina, having heard enough, closes the door on her mother's ranting and raving. ANGLE--TINA Tina bends down and scoops her baby son HECTOR up from the bed and holds him for dear life to her breasts.  She talks to her son while walking around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector, I shouldn't be telling you this but you would find out sooner or later.  Ya father ain't no real father.  He's a bum, a two-bit bum in a hundred-dollar world.  Your father is to the curb.  You're smart.  I see that look on ya face. You're saying if he's such a bum why am I with him?  Good question. Like I said before, you're no dummy. He talked his way into my panties, I thought being a mother would make me happy, make me whole.  He's a mistake, but you are not. Tina kisses her son.  Tina is seventeen years old, another teenage parent. EXT: STREET CORNER--DAY Every day on this corner, summer or winter, spring or fall, a small group of men meet.  They have no steady employment, nothing they can speak of; they do, however, have the gift of gab.  These man can talk, talk, and mo' talk, and when a bottle is going round and they're feeling "nice," they get philosophical.  These men become the great thinkers of the world, with solutions to all its ills; like drugs, the homeless, and AIDS.  They're called the Corner Men: SWEET DICK WILLIE, COCONUT SID, and ML.  All three are sitting in folding chairs up against a wall in the shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way I see it, if this hot weather continues, it will surely melt the polar caps and the whole wide world--the parts that ain't water already--will be flooded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You a dumb-ass simple motherfucker. Where did you read that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it.  But when it happens and I'm in my boat and ya black ass is drowning, don't ask me to throw you a lifesaver either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fool, you're thirty cents away from a quarter.  How you gonna get a boat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're raggedy as a roach.  You eat the holes out of donuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be back on my feet.  Soon enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So when is all this ice suppose to melt? INT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY Customers are in Sal's; it's lunchtime and it's fairly busy. Sal puts a hot slice down on the counter in front of BUGGIN' OUT, a b-boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You paying now or on layaway? Buggin' Out looks at the slice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You come in here at least three times a day.  You a retard?  A buck fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, Sal, put some more cheese on that motherfucker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extra cheese is two dollars. Y'know dat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two dollars!  Forget it! Buggin' Out slams his money down on the counter, takes his slice and sits down. ANGLE--TABLE All around Buggin' Out, peering down from the WALL OF FAME, are signed, framed, eight by ten glossies of famous Italian Americans.  WE SEE Joe DiMaggio, Rocky Marciano, Perry Como, Frank Sinatra, Luciano Pavarotti, Liza Minnelli, Governor Mario Cuomo, Al Pacino and, of course, how can we forget Sylvester Stallone as Rocky Balboa: THE ITALIAN STALLION, also RAMBO. CLOSE UP--BUGGIN' OUT He looks at the pictures hovering above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mookie. CLOSE UP--MOOKIE MOOKIE What? CLOSE UP--BUGGIN' OUT BUGGIN' OUT How come you ain't got no brothers up? CLOSE UP--MOOKIE MOOKIE Ask Sal. ANGLE--PIZZERIA
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sal, how come you ain't got no brothers up on the wall here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want brothers up on the Wall of Fame, you open up your own business, then you can do what you wanna do. My pizzeria, Italian Americans up on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy, Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't start on me today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sal, that might be fine, you own this, but rarely do I see any Italian Americans eating in here. All I've ever seen is Black folks. So since we spend much money here, we do have some say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You a troublemaker? Pino walks over to Buggin' Out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You making trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put some brothers up on this Wall of Fame.  We want Malcolm X, Angela Davis, Michael Jordan tomorrow. Sal comes from behind the counter with his Louisville Slugger Mickey Mantle model baseball bat.  Vito is by his side, but Mookie intercepts them, and takes Buggin' Out outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't come back, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boycott Sal's.  Boycott Sal's. EXT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY MOOKIE Buggin' Out, I gotta work here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm cool.  I'm cool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back in a week, it will be squashed. They give each other five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY Mookie enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mookie, if your friends can't behave, they're not welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got no say over people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You talk to 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People are free to do what they wanna do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, this is America, but I don't want no trouble. EXT: STREET--DAY Mookie walks down the block with pizza box in hand when he sees Da Mayor sitting on his stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gotta go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mere, Doctor. Mookie turns around and goes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor, this is Da Mayor talkin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  OK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor, always try to do the right thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it. INT: TENEMENT BUILDING--DAY Mookie is hiking up a flight of stairs. ANGLE--STAIRCASE He puts the pizza box down and takes a breather. CLOSE UP--MOOKIE Sweat drips off his face. ANGLE--MOOKIE He bends down to pick up the pizza box and tackles the last few flights. CLOSE UP--DOORBELL Mookie pushes the buzzer. ANGLE--DOOR A young Puerto Rican woman opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope it's not cold. Mookie hands her the pizza.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's not cold.  Twelve dollars for the pie. Nilda hands him a handful of singles.  Mookie looks at the crumpled mess.  Nilda attempts to close the door, but Mookie's foot says, "Hell no."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold it.  Let me count this first. First he straightens out the dollars, then counts the bills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I counted the twelve dollars myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twelve is right, but no tip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No tip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, lady.  I carried your pizza up five flights of stairs and shit. The cheese didn't slide over to one side like it sometimes does with delivery people who don't care.  I do care.  May I get paid? Nilda looks at him and sees right away he's not going anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait. Nilda goes into the apartment and we hear her talking in Spanish to a male. ANGLE--MOOKIE Mookie bends down to tie his sneakers. ANGLE--DOOR Nilda reappears and holds out a lonely lone dollar for him. Mookie has her hold it out for awhile, then he takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gracias mucho. Nilda slams the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dollar!  Cheap bastard!  Your pizza is gonna be fucked next time. EXT: MOTHER SISTER'S STOOP--DAY Jade sits down next to Mother Sister on the stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jade, you're late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Mother Sister, but I'm here now.  Where's the stuff? Mother Sister hands her a bag that is at her side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seen your brother, just walked by. Jade unwraps a head scarf from around Mother Sister's head and a full head of long black hair falls to her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This might take some time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got nowhere to go.  We haven't had a good sit-down for a long while. Jade begins to part, grease, and comb out Mother Sister's hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tender-headed runs in my family. You tender-headed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, me too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I don't fool with it. Only let you touch it...Ouch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, comb got caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be gentle, child.  Mother Sister is an old woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you holding up in this weather?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know why you still haven't bought an air conditioner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't like 'em.  A fan will do. ANGLE--DA MAYOR Da Mayor stands in front of the stoop, he's smiling for days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know you had such beautiful hair. ANGLE--STOOP
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fool, there's a lot in this world you don't know. CLOSE UP--DA MAYOR DA MAYOR I'm not stopping.  I'm on my way. The Mayor tips his hat and heads up the block. ANGLE--STOOP
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are too cruel to Da Mayor, it isn't right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not studying no Mayor.  Besides, he reminds me of my least favorite peoples.  My tenants and my ex- husband--Goddamn-bless his soul. They both laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Number One: I got some jive, late- rent-paying trifling Negroes in this house.  Every year I keep threatening to sell it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And move to Long Island...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And move to Long Island.  Number Two: my ex-husband lost all my property, all my money in his scheme to build a Black business empire.  Needless to say what happened, this house is it, all I got.  I'm too through with yar people. CLOSE UP--JADE JADE Whew!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She looks up at the white-hot sun. CLOSE UP--MOTHER SISTER She does the same. X CLOSE UP--THE WHITE-HOT SUN HOT, HOTTER AND HOTTEST MONTAGE Right now, folks, we're gonna suspend the narrative and show how people are coping with the oppressive heat. People are taking cold showers. Sticking faces in ice-cold, water-filled sinks. Heads stuck in refrigerators. A wife tells her husband, "Hell no, I'm not cooking.  It's too hot.  The kitchen is closed." Men downing six-packs of ice-cold brew. Faces stuck directly in front of fans. A young kid cracks an egg on Sal's Cadillac.  The moment the egg hits the car hood it starts to cook.  The kid looks directly INTO THE CAMERA and smiles, then looks up to see Sal, mad as a motherfucker, chasing after him. INT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--NIGHT CLOSE--PHOTOS Some burnt photos on the floor. CLOSE--MICKEY MANTLE BAT The Mickey Mantle bat burns. CLOSE--RADIO RAHEEM'S BOX Radio Raheem's box has melted into a black mass of goo. CLOSER--RADIO RAHEEM'S BOX 87. As WE MOVE IN TIGHTER ON the melted box, we begin to hear the rap song that we've hear throughout.  All other sound drops as the rap song gets louder and louder until it's deafening. ANGLE--SMILEY Smiley sits up from where he hid during the burning and looting of Sal's Famous Pizzeria.  Smiley looks around and goes directly to the smoldering Wall of Fame.  He stands there.  Smiley pins one of his Malcolm X/Martin Luther King, Jr., cards to the Wall of Fame. CLOSE--PHOTO CLOSE--SMILEY We're on Smiley's face and a smile slowly travels across. It's the first time Smiley has smiled in years and nobody is there to see this event. FADE TO BLACK THE MORNING AFTER FADE IN: EXT: THE STREET--TO INT: RADIO STATION STOREFRONT--DAY The CAMERA, FROM HIGH ABOVE, CRANES DOWN ON The Block.  The sidewalk is deserted, broken glass is everywhere, and it looks exactly as how one expects it to look, the morning after an uprising. The CAMERA NOW MOVES IN ON the WE LOVE storefront where Mister Senor Love Daddy is in his familiar place behind the mike.
direction.name: direction

Together are we gonna live?  This is ya Mister Senor Love Daddy here on WE LOVE RADIO, 108 FM on your dial, and that's the truth, Ruth. CLOSE--MISTER SENOR LOVE DADDY 88.

direction.raw_text: We're still standing. Da Mayor and Mother Sister both look out the parlor window to see THE BLOCK and Mookie. EXT: SAL'S FAMOUS PIZZERIA--DAY Mookie walks up to Sal's Famous Pizzeria as it still smoulders in the morning light.  Sal emerges from the wreckage; he looks like he might have slept there.

direction.raw_text: Whatdafuck do you want?

direction.raw_text: I got it. EXT: STREET--DAY HIGH ANGLE As Mookie turns and walks away, Sal goes back into Sal's Famous Pizzeria to salvage what is salvageable, and The Block begins to awake from its slumber, ready to deal once again with the heat of the hottest day of the year.
